reviewText: Wow, that was deeply unsettling. Blink Twice sets the table and then just kinda of lets you stew in a sense of unease before finally revealing itself. From there it gets wild. I never thought much of Channing Tatum as an actor but he’s perfectly cast here, delivering a mix of charm and menace. The ending is *chef’s kiss*.

There’s a lot to love here, particularly Daniel Day-Lewis’ performance as Bill the Butcher. It feels like both DiCaprio and Diaz are miscast and Scorsese just tries to do too much at the end. There’s a lot of build-up to a climactic confrontation that’s largely disrupted by a historical event. This movie is probably more relevant to today’s political climate than it was in 2002. If only we could see we should be fighting the “$300 men” instead of each other.
Incredible. A feast for the eyes. Riveting from beginning to end. Perhaps my favorite Eggers film so far. Willem Dafoe is my king.

This “documentary” is like “Somebody Should Do Something About All the Problems” framed in a vague speculative fiction dystopia. It lists off problems that, to no one’s surprise, are bad! And if left unchecked, could lead to a disastrous future, as if it’s not already here. It asks us to take action before it’s too late but has no ideas about what those actions might be. One of the many problems it covers is AI, but it seems like AI was used to make the doc? 84 minutes of my life I’ll never get back.
Well that was bleak.
Gorgeous 4K transfer. The last 20 minutes of this is perfect. Even after maybe a dozen viewings it’s still incredibly tense.

This was really bizarre to watch as I recognized aspects of myself in both Kieran Culkin and Jesse Eisenberg’s characters that are often in conflict. It was like seeing my inner voice projected on the screen. Their journey together and their interactions with the people around them almost felt like set dressing to inform the relationship between these two cousins. I’ll have to give it another watch. The last shot shook me.
I like Nate but his dry, clean humor doesn’t elicit much more than a hearty chuckle from me.

Struggled to stay awake through this as I was doped up on NyQuil as my wife and I watched this in a hotel room, both struggling with some unknown virus. On top of that the hotel TV had motion-smoothing turned on, which was extremely distracting. All that said, this movie still slaps. Incredible score and just a fun horny time with three great leads.
Amy Adams is great in this spin on Teen Wolf. Lots to relate to here as tired parent.

Not sure this needed to have such a non-linear narrative, except “time” is in the title, so I guess? I enjoyed the chemistry between Garfield and Pugh, but it probably would have worked the same as a conventional narrative. Some good moments but ultimately I don’t think it was terribly memorable.

Absolutely chilling. Feels very of the moment with our obsession with true crime and its depiction of the dark web. Juliette Gariépy delivers an incredible performance, creepy and understated at the same time. This movie kept me guessing until the very end.

My mom told me she once invited a Jehovah's Witness in for a chat and they by the time they left they were no longer a Jehovah's Witness and now I have questions. Anyway, this was fiendishly clever and it seems like the type of movie that will benefit from repeat viewings. Chilling performance from Hugh Grant.

"...this rabble you're talking about, they do most of the working and paying and living and dying in this community. Well, is it too much to have them work and pay and live and die in a couple of decent rooms and a bath?"Turns out we're all living in Pottersville and Mr. Potter is President-elect.

Kyle Mooney's humor is definitely not for everyone but this movie had me laughing my ass off. Heavy on the late 90s nostalgia and includes maybe the best cameo of the year. Brilliantly spoofs movies of that era and mixes genres in a fun way. It's almost a millennial Wet Hot American Summer. Didn't love this as much as Brigsby Bear but was not disappointed.

I dug the 80s aesthetic here and loved Jude Law as a grizzled FBI agent chasing down a group of white nationalists. The whole thing didn't add up to much, mostly because there's just not enough time to develop its characters. There's definitely some Heat and Sicario influences at play but The Order lacks the depth of those films. Might have been better as the next season of True Detective.

Watched this again with my wife and it was delightful watching her squirm and squeal through the increasingly disturbing moments. Props to Demi for reading this script and going, "hell yes, let's do this."

Real TV movie of the week vibes. 12 Angry Men meets Idiocracy. There's so many elements that strain credulity and the ending was pretty unsatisfying. I'm not sure if people are giving this a pass because Eastwood directed it or if I saw a completely different movie. Yeesh.

Very much Force Majeure with zombies. The first two-thirds or so is pretty action-packed. It kind of loses steam towards the end. Looks better than the first movie just by virtue of using a better camera but lacks Danny Boyle's style. Great to see Jeremy Renner, Idris Elba and Rose Byrne before they were household names. Turns out bringing Americans in to solve your problems is maybe not the best idea.

Completely nonsensical plot. It didn't help that I didn't see Sonic 2. But my 5-year-old was excited to see this in the theater — only his third movie in one. I spent most of the runtime trying to get my 2-year-old to sit still and not be a complete nuisance but my overall impression was that it was visually interesting and had double the Jim Carrey, which I had no complaints about. My kids gave it two thumbs up, take that as you will.

Such a great setup for a zombie movie but the middle lags quite a bit and it turns out that men are more sick than zombies. The final act is pretty satisfying though. It's a shame this movie looks so terrible as it was shot on a Canon XL 1. It'll be interesting to see Boyle revisit this with 28 Years Later.

Superman was one of the first movies I remember seeing in the theater. It really captured my imagination and Christopher Reeve's performance a huge part of it. I don't know that I ever saw him in anything else until after he passed. He was just always Superman. This doc mostly covers his life after being paralyzed, his advocacy for the disabled, and the family, friends, and legacy he left behind. It had me in tears for most of the last 20 minutes. It's devastating to see our heroes fall but some manage to rise up and be more heroic than ever. Reeve was certainly one of those heroes.
Gorgeous 4k remaster. This movie is a slow burn but the last half hour is so remarkable it's haunted me since the first time I saw it.

An absolute masterpiece. I love this movie more each time I see it. The thing I noticed most this time around is how much happens off screen. The story and characters are so well put together that they don’t even need to show you things that other movies would relish making a scene of. Great performances all around and gorgeous cinematography by Deakins.

Way more fun than it has any right to be. The plot is ridiculous but the cast is stacked with a who's who of great character actors. Taron Egerton is solid, if not overqualified to be a TSA agent. A lot of comparisons to Die Hard, but this is more like Phone Booth except it's actually enjoyable.

Stylish and fun in a way that Guy Ritchie excels at. I watched reruns of the show as a kid and, while it was fun, it never looked this cool. It’s a shame that Armie Hammer turned out to be a weird vampire sex perv or whatever. I would have loved for this to be a franchise. Also on second watch I realized that Jared Harris plays Solo’s boss, doing a hilariously bad American accent and I loved every minute of it.

It came as no surprise in this special when Jeselnik talked about his comedy hero, Norm MacDonald. Both he and Norm have a similar deadpan style where you don’t know where a joke is going but when the punchline drops it’s almost always a surprise. Jeselnik tells a bunch of stories from his 20 years in stand up with such bravado, never once cracking a smile at his own jokes. I can’t say his humor is for everybody but I laughed my ass off.

I wanted to revisit this with Kyle Mooney’s new movie, Y2K coming out this week. I think this was my favorite movie of 2017 and I still love it the second time around. Mooney plays it with such earnestness that you really care for his character. Shades of Be Kind, Rewind and The Truman Show. Mark Hamill is perfectly cast. Now I’m really stoked to check out Y2K.

I appreciate Supercop more than I love it. It’s truly a miracle that no one died making this movie, particularly Michelle Yeoh, who is absolutely fearless and very much Jackie’s equal in terms of skill and screen presence. The plot is ridiculously over-the-top but grounded with humor, like many of Jackie’s movies. Props to the stunt team who managed several set pieces on par with modern Mission: Impossible movies years earlier. There are very few movie stars that would risk their lives just to entertain us for a couple of hours but I’m glad they exist.

I was so happy to revisit this gorgeous movie on 4K bluray. It had been a long time since I’d last seen it but it really holds up as one of the best wuxia films of all time. Great cast, stunning cinematography and a moving score.

One of my favorite Coen Brothers movies, I must have seen it a dozen times but probably not in at least 15 years or so. Clooney is so wacky and charming and the supporting cast is wonderful, like most Coen movies. All these years later it felt like it lost some of its luster but it’s still a fun time.

First time revisiting this and it’s still pretty great. Some of the dialogue hasn’t aged well but that could be said for a lot of 20-year-old movies. Downey Jr and Kilmer have great chemistry. Love how this movie subverts cliches left and right. I wish Shane Black just made a career doing screwball buddy detective movies like this and The Nice Guys.

More like MEN TALKING, amirite? In all seriousness, as an atheist, I didn't expect to be so riveted by this movie. Gorgeously shot and almost plays like a murder mystery. So many twists and turns culminating in such a fantastic and timely reveal. Gave me hope that maybe good can ultimately prevail in the face of a bunch of shitty men.

Joined my wife mid-way through this and then went back and watched the parts I missed. What an odd movie. I'm almost not sure where this movie stands on the issue of abortion but it could prove to be a lot more relevant if the Project 2025 weirdos have their way.

Darkly funny, which I was not at all expecting. Part Charlie Kaufman, part David Cronenberg. Adam Pearson is so outrageously confident and Renate Reinsve is delightful. This would make a great double feature with The Substance.
This movie never gets old. So many good lines. Epic score. Rousing action. Revisiting this after the sequel (which I quite enjoyed) only elevated the greatness of the original for me.

I had low expectations going into this because the marketing for the movie ruined the whole premise but I had great time with it. Funny and gory, it should have come as no surprise that this was made by the team behind Ready or Not. Dan Stevens is great, as always, but just about everyone in the cast brings something unique. This movie is a ton of fun.

Classic 90s action movie. Highly implausible but peak Keanu and Sandra Bullock make it work. Dennis Hopper feels miscast as the villain. Maybe with better writing it wouldn't have been as noticable, but I give it a pass because Hopper is Hopper and this movie is just non-stop thrills. Couldn't tell you anything about Speed 2 without confusing it with Under Seige but the first one slaps.

I’m growing weary of all these “lega-sequels” but I was, in fact, entertained! Paul Mescal takes up the mantle for Russell Crowe’s Maximus, whose presence looms large over the movie, and does a serviceable job. Denzel Washington is just having a blast here. He’s bringing Training Day energy, which would otherwise seem out of place if it weren’t for the comically over-the-top twin emperors of Rome. The set pieces are solid and the whole affair leads up to a rousing and satisfying conclusion. Love that Ridley Scott is still banging out movies, even if they don’t all hit as hard as this one.

The setup of this movie is so brilliantly economical. Seeing this in the theater before Arnold became a superstar and Terminator 2 became a pop culture phenomenon, the night club scene must have been wild. The shootout at the police station must have seemed utterly terrifying but today it’s just a Tuesday. The effects don’t hold up very well, particularly in the otherwise gorgeous 4K transfer, but this is such a well-crafted film and a template for Cameron’s later work that would go on to shatter box office records again and again.

I was interested in checking out this early work of Jonathan Glazer and it did not disappoint. From the very beginning, like Nicole Kidman, you’re not fully convinced whether 10-year-old Cameron Bright is actually the reincarnation of her dead husband. The score is both chilling and whimsical at times, and the cast features some great supporting actors, including Danny Huston, who plays Kidman’s (adult) fiancée. Watching him unravel as Kidman gets pulled deeper into this kid’s story culminates in such a delightful way. I really had no idea where this was going until the very end.

A short and sweet coming-of-age movie with a dash of magic(?), for lack of a better word. I was expecting it to lean a bit more into its initial premise but it keeps it at arms length. Aubrey Plaza and Maisy Stella couldn’t be more different but they make it work. And I randomly watched back-to-back movies with Percy Hynes White, who is charming and down-to-earth here. I was ready to write this off as just another breezy rom-com but the ending really landed for me and reminded me of one of my favorite movies that I won’t name because that would spoil this one.

Despite finding nearly every character in this movie unlikable and entitled, I was captivated the whole time. I would describe Anora as Pretty Woman meets Uncut Gems. Mikey Madison gives a really brave performance. Sean Baker again shows he’s a unique and incredibly talented filmmaker. I was surprised how funny this movie was. Also, it’s clear the actor that plays Vanya never played a video game in his life.

A really sweet and earnest coming-of-age movie. I also like movies and grew up in the video store age, so I found a lot to relate to. Isaiah Lehtinen is really great and believably awkward as the lead character, Lawrence. I almost wish the movie was longer than its 100 minute run time. I would have liked to see more of Lawrence and his manager Alana’s relationship develop. It seemed a little rushed.

This movie is painfully long but I have to give it props for its sheer ambition and scope. Kirk Douglas is such a charmer you can believe he’d be able to lead a slave uprising. Given recent events I was all jazzed when the slaves were eating the rich but uh, well, I guess we’re all truly fucked.

A slow burn until it reveals itself mid-way through and then the pace picks up dramatically. Not sure I found the end particularly satisfying but it’s a compelling watch. The less you know going in, the better.

Very rarely do I find myself watching a movie and realizing that it will be among my all-time favorites before the credits even roll, but THE SUBSTANCE grabbed me from the start. Coralie Fargeat’s follow-up to 2017’s excellent Revenge is so confident and well-executed. It “yes ands” itself to absurd heights (depths?) in a way that elicited such joy that I couldn’t help wish I had seen this opening night in a packed screening. Demi Moore and Margaret Qualley are excellent. Fargeat asks a lot from them and they deliver. I don’t know that I can recommend this to literally anyone but for me, it was perfect.

A deeply moving documentary that recreates the online life of its subject in a unique, if at times cheesy, way. It’s a loving tribute to a person who touched so many lives despite his physical limitations. But it’s also an examination of how people use video games as an escape, while also being able to form deep and meaningful connections with others. Keep the tissues handy. (I learned after watching this that it’s by the same director as The Painter and the Thief, another excellent documentary.)

As contrived as this thriller was I thought it was pretty entertaining. Finn Whitrock is right at home as creepy white guy and Kelsey Asbille does a decent job with very little dialogue. But man, five minutes into this movie and I’m like, “hasn’t this lady been through enough already?”
Creepy and unsettling. Zovatto is great here, giving strong Vincent D’Onofrio vibes. A solid debut feature for Anna Kendrick, who spends less time on screen than I’d imagined.

I was predisposed to liking this, having grown up with SNL (we both turn 50 in 2025) . This is an earnest and loving imagining(?) of the 90 minutes leading up to the first episode. I’m sure very little of this happened that night and characterizations of real life people are far from accurate, but like the show Winning Time, I couldn’t care less because the subject matter is something I enjoy and have deep knowledge about. Love the casting — the SNL regulars were largely unknown to me but each do a passable job of capturing the essence of their real life counterparts. The more known actors around them are inspired casting. I wish the movie had spent more time fleshing out the main SNL cast, it gives particularly short shrift to the female cast members, spending most of its runtime following Lorne Michaels. It’s still quite enjoyable, though probably less so if you’re not familiar with SNL lore, particularly those early years. I can imagine this being nearly unintelligible without that context. When they finally say the iconic opening line, I got a little choked up.

Appreciate the ambition of MadS, even if it felt a little hollow. The characters mostly just exist to move the plot forward and I never felt any attachment to them. Laurie Pavy was really going for it though. Enjoyed watching her transformation. Not sure this movie needed to be a oner, but the execution was solid.
